snippet: As a river in Washington State returns to its original state because of a dam removal project, fish again swim upstream — but tons of sediment are heading downstream.
abstract: Port Angeles Journal; restoration of the Elwha River in Washington State, by removing two dams that all but killed it, is bringing back the fish but is also creating a mind-bogglingly large surge of sediment; scientists say no other dam removal project in the nation comes close to the earth-load in the Elwha, and most of it, after decades in the making, has yet to come down the river.
lead_paragraph: As a river in Washington State returns to its original state because of a dam removal project, fish again swim upstream — but tons of sediment are heading downstream.

headline.seo: Elwha River, Undammed and Newly Murky
headline.main: A River Newly Wild and Seriously Muddy
headline.print_headline: A River Newly Wild and Seriously Muddy
